title: Contributing
text:
This is a community open source project to gather and share wisdom from the CZI EOSS Community. Organizational Mycology works to faciltiate theses resources on behalf of the EOSS Community.
We are looking for contributions that add topics and enhance our resources for the benefit of other Open Source Leaders.


By contributing, you agree that we may redistribute your work under our license
You agree to abide by the CZI Community Participation Guidelines in this space.



The easiest way to get started is to file an issue to tell us about a spelling mistake, some awkward wording, or a factual error. This is a good way to introduce yourself and to meet some of our community members.

If you do not have a [GitHub][github] account, you can [send us comments by email][contact]. However, we will be able to respond more quickly if you use one of the other methods described below.
If you have a [GitHub][github] account, or are willing to [create one][github-join], but do not know how to use Git, you can report problems or suggest improvements by [creating an issue][issues]. This allows us to assign the item to someone and to respond to it in a threaded discussion.
If you are comfortable with Git, and would like to add or change material, you can submit a pull request (PR).

This contributor guide was adapted from that of Software Carpentry, The Carpentries

title: Governance Signals and Strategies for Open Source Scientific Projects
text:
In this document, we share insights discussed in the Chan-Zuckerberg Initiative’s Essential Open Source Software program community call held on July 24, 2025.
This resource is intended to be a conversation-starter for open source software project leaders, their collaborators, staff, and community.
The topics contained in the first version of this document reflect only what we discussed on the CZI EOSS community call. We encourage suggestions and contributions to expand the scope of scaling strategies that open source project leaders should consider when managing a project, as well as resources that would be helpful to leaders and their projects.

title: Governance Signals and Strategies for Open Source Scientific Projects
text:
Developing a Healthy Governance Approach


Principles for Effective Governance:

Mission-Centered

Always return to the project’s core mission

Governance should serve the project’s goals

Transparency is better than specific structural details



Inclusive Participation

Actively solicit underrepresented voices

Create multiple entry points for contribution

Value non-code contributions

Be open by default




Practical Strategies:

Proactive Review Processes

Talk about governance early and often in project development

Schedule regular governance check-ins

Use external moderators when possible

Conduct periodic community exercises to realign on values



Succession and Sustainability

Implement shadowing/mentorship programs

Continuously train potential future leaders, maintainers, and core team members

Create systems that outlast individual contributors



Community Engagement

Establish clear communication channels

Provide opportunities for constructive feedback

Create smaller working groups

Normalize discussing governance openly

title: Governance Signals and Strategies for Open Source Scientific Projects
text:
Recommended Implementation Steps


Document current processes

Identify potential governance challenges

Create transparent decision-making frameworks

Build in flexibility for future evolution

Prioritize community well-being


Warning: Common Pitfalls

Resisting change

Centralizing too much power

Ignoring community feedback

Treating governance as a static concept

text: This resource was generated as part of CZI’s EOSS Community Calls during late 2024 with Organizational Mycology facilitating discussions, gathering input, and generating the final document. Participants in the calls, and open comment periods are given co-authorship in alphabetical order by last name.
